description: From the Latin cohaereō (“I cohere, I cling (closely) together, I harmonise, I am consistent (with), I am in agreement with”).

verbs.description: cohere (third-person singular simple present coheres, present participle cohering, simple past and past participle cohered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To stick together physically, by adhesion.
examples: Separate molecules will cohere because of electromagnetic force.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To be consistent as part of a group, or by common purpose.
examples: Members of the party would cohere in the message they were sending.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To be consistent as part of a group, or by common purpose.
examples: This division suggests that Khamenei is not playing his usual role of cohering the regime during a crisis.
